Absence of myostatin does result in increased muscle mass in individuals but these muscles do not contract as hard and fast as in individuals with normal levels pf myostatin. http://www.pnas.org/content/104/6/1835.long
Also a lower level of myostatin results in weaker connective tissue and more risk of injuries. So absence of myostatin may make an individual muscular but that does not necessarily mean stronger.

The people talking about steroids need to read more. It is true anabolic steroids do make it easier to gain muscle mass. That said if you sit on you sofa and take steroids with no exercise and no increased protein intake at best you will gain about 3lbs. to 10lbs. of muscle mass. That is not that much given the dosages involved. 

What people fail to understand is that steroids work by increasing nutrient absorption from food you are eating and they speed up how quickly your body recovers from exercise. You have to be working out really hard and often and eating correctly to benefit from higher anabolic hormone levels. 

In fact to make it worth the health risks of taking steroids at higher then therapeutic levels one must workout really hard and really often! 

Growth Hormone on the other hand works no matter if you work out or not and this is even more true when talking about younger people that have not entered puberty or are currently in puberty. The freak show really starts to happen though when Growth Hormone, Anabolic Steroids and Insulin are administered combined with hard training. 

Depending on other side effects I would rather people have some sort of alternative to that combo if all they want is cosmetics and a myostatin blocking drug seems like a huge improvement over what is in use now.

Your heart is entirely muscle. Low or non-existent myostatin result in an enlarged heart. Enlarged hearts are not good as they can lead to congestive heart failure.

The gene is actually called the MSTN gene, and GDF-8 or Growth Differentiation Factor 8 is another name for the protein Myostatin. Also, myostatin is also expressed (at low levels) in the heart to prevent hypertrophy of the heart. Conversely, an increased concentration of myostatin is found in patients with heart failure or dilated cardiomyopathy (a weakened, enlarged heart). What this all means, is that blocking myostatin could be beneficial for people with heart disease, but there is a possibility it leads to heart disease in healthy people. Our genome contains the MSTN gene for a reason and it's tightly regulated, so don't mess with it.

Normally bone density is proportional to muscle torque. Our bones have to be able to withstand the torque of our muscles, without snapping. Myostatin is produce primarily in the skeletal muscles. Lack of myostatin could very well throw off the balance of muscle torque, and bone density, causing degeneration, and damage to the frame. 

Donald Hebb was onced asked what played more of a rule in developing the personality, genetics, or environment (which is just the age old nature/nurture duality) to which he said "what contributes more to the area of a rectangle, its length or its width? Point being that genetics are activated and deactivated by the environment. Spontaneous genetic mutation itself is caused by the environment. The two cannot be disentangled in order to claim that one contributes more to any given trait than the other. One suggesting this is only talking about the age old (not scientifically informed) nature vs nurture debate, and aren't talking about the science that tells us that such a debate is nonsense to begin with.

Saying that muscle size and strength is determined by genetics is a woefully mis informed statement.

Although genetics does have a part to play in muscle growth, a more significant part is epigenetics. Various chemical pathways result in a protein which will bind to the active site on a strand of DNA and inhibit transcription. This means that through activities your genes will be expressed differently. Various activities will inhibit myostatin, estrogen, and cortisol synethesis such as eating a diet with saturated fats and cholesterol and exercising, weight lifting has shown to have an incredible effect on genetic expression.

this video might give the illusion that myostatin deficient people are superhumans. there is a reason myostatin exists:

firstly; a larger muscle requires more calories and nutrients such as vitamins and minerals to maintain,
secondly, a simply big muscle doesn't operate as well as a smaller one. the blood flow gets obstructed due to the sheer bulk of the muscle fibers. It works very well with anaerobic exercise but very poorly with aerobic exercise.

bodybuilders are strong, but they have very low endurance. And let's not forget that while bones and muscles are easy to repair, your joints are much more prone to wear and tear since it doesn't have a blood supply, but instead gets it's nutrients from diffusion alone, and there isn't much you can do about it.

also, having more muscles doesn't eliminate the need to exercise. if you just want to look athletic, you can as well get silicon muscle implants like some insecure bumtards out there.
